fields.description:
Came in to Niall over email, it's from CS.

I have just updated ag-grid version in one of our applications, and I have noticed non-backward compatible behaviour of ensureNodeVisible() API method. Previous behaviour was that when node is visible, then grid is not scrolled.

Now I see new parameter position in the API: ensureNodeVisible(comparator, position), but reading documentation, when this parameter is null or undefined, then function should behave this same:
https://www.ag-grid.com/javascript-grid-api/#gsc.tab=0
“If top, middle or bottom, the grid will scroll the row to place the row at top, middle or bottom. If undefined or null then grid will do the minimum scrolling to show the row”
 
Now from my observations it behaves different and scrolls always. After little investigation I have found this revision:
https://github.com/ag-grid/ag-grid/commit/3c92d76a80804479f84dd2b3929c80192af8c078
public ensureNodeVisible(comparator:any, position:string = 'top')
fields.summary: ensureNodeVisible non-backward compatible behaviour

fields.description:
With Angular CLI 1.5 (the latest) if you run ng build --prod then the following error will be thrown:

ERROR in ./node_modules/ag-grid/dist/lib/gridOptionsWrapper.js
Module build failed: RangeError: Maximum call stack size exceeded
 
This will be intermittent (say 3 out of 5 builds will fail) but it is reproducible. I believe that this error is down to the cyclic deps we have in core.

A reliable workaround is to have this in package.json:

    "prod": "node --stack_size=8048 node_modules/.bin/ng build --prod",

Which increases the amount of available memory
fields.summary: Angular CLI 1.5 - ng build --prod causes a stack error

fields.description:
Pressing control-enter in an editor clears the cell content and doesn't close the editor.

The control-enter triggers a keypress event after the keydown (which is closing the editor, as expected). CellComp.onKeyPress reads the charCode as 10 (instead of 13 for 'enter'), which is processed as a \n character. This goes to Utils.isEventFromPrintableCharacter which incorrectly classifies the \n as printable. Then, because the user has 'input' a 'printable' character on a cell that's not editing, it starts editing, using \n as the initially typed character.
fields.summary: [edit] Ctrl-Enter resets cell editor to blank

fields.description:
the user on github says that the order of the rows in the dom is not consistent with the order of the rows in the grid, so when you tab into the grid, it's the first row in the dom that gets the focus, not the first row in the grid.

this is how the grid should work, the rows are not necessarily added in the order they appear.

options to fix:
1) when user tabs into the grid, somehow put the focus on the first row - which would be tricky if the user is scrolled down.
2) let the user decide somehow how to handle this. i think this is a can of worms, however if we can document somehow to the user can catch the tab event, and then let them decide which row / cell gets the focus, then this would all go away.


niall thought - have thought about this a lot, and think with row virtualisation (ie the first rendered row will not be row 1, and won't even be the first row on the screen with the rowBuffer), so i am deciding on option 1 above. i see some interesting ideas on the link here:
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/10731468/override-default-tabbing-navigation
in particular, i think the onus should be on the user to put a listener on the last item they have, and then they do some gridApi calls to maybe 1) scroll grid to first row and then 2) put focus on first cell.
fields.summary: [tabbing] tabbing into the grid goes into the wrong cell

fields.description:
Not easy to reproduce, but click around, sort etc and eventually a hamburger will appear

This is confusing to users as it implies it can be clicked on.

Niall note - I went to look into this - it's tricky, as we don't know when the user is on iPad or a device where we should not be showing the hamburger. We could check for touch, however some devices (eg touch screen windows machines) allow both touch and mouse, so cannot be 'one or the other'. One solution would be to suppress the hamburger in the menu - however I'd like to take a step back and think about how the headers are configured rather than hack a fix in for this (the fix would be a property 'suppressHamburger' which the user would set, and suppress the hamburger but still allow the touch support for showing the menu). . . . . . . or we do nothing and just live with it, fixing it would cause other issues (eg if we got the grid to not show the hamburger, then we would not show it sometimes when the user wants it shown).
fields.summary: [iPad] hamburger occasionally appears but cannot be clicked

fields.description:
The new editor mechanism uses mergeDeep - when a user passes in an nrgx store value the stack will overflow.

This didn't happen in the older mechanism, primarily because it didn't make use of mergeDeep

Plunker attached in the forum post

Problem is in ComponentResolver.createAgGridComponent's useof mergeParams.

The second line in that method will hang:

        _.mergeDeep(finalParams, customParams);


Also here
      https://ag-grid.com/forum/showthread.php?tid=6497
fields.summary: [regression] new component editor uses mergeDeep - causes stack overflow when certain observables are used

fields.description:
After hitting end, if focus goes to a cell that is not rendered, the focus is lost, and the navigation keys stop working.

Niall Note - this is because the cells are not rendered in time - the code was missing "this.animationFrameService.flushAllFrames();"

however having said that - i'm not sure the code is the best - we already have logic for ensureColumnVisible() and ensureIndesVisible(), so am not sure if we should be doing pixel logic again here. i've checked in an alternative method pageDiagonally_new(), which fixes this problem, but the end result is less code that is easier to follow.

fields.description:
allow grid to fill with empty rows.

we should only implement this if there is an elegant solution.

We are going to reject this one, but we are going to sugar coat it with a plunkr that shows how to style the body of the grid for the area with no rows. Even though it seems like the guy has already implemented a similar solution, at least we will sugar coat the rejection since there is a renewal in the line!

This one is too niche and too difficult to implement. There are a couple of things to note though:

Have a look at this, this will make your grid adjust to your given height
https://www.ag-grid.com/javascript-grid-width-and-height/?framework=javascript#example-auto-height

And also, as the customer probably already knows, they can style the empty portion of the grid with:

.ag-body-viewport {
    background-color: yellow;
}

Note that the yellow background is an example.

Up to the user to style anyway they want
fields.summary: [rows] allow grid to fill with empty rows

fields.description:
We are using gridOptions.api.ensureIndexVisible() function to display search records (not a filter). 

ag-Grid displays these record at the bottom or the top of the list (i.e. as a last or first row), depending on their position in the database. 

Ideally, found records should be displayed in the center of the list because that's where the eyes of the users are usually directed, and not at the top or bottom of the list. This problem becomes especially acute on large displays. 

We've reviewed your documentation a number of times, and weren't able to find a direct way to remedy this issue.
fields.summary: [api] Display of Found Records Following Search

fields.description:
In grid.ts : RowModelClasses we have "infinite" and "normal"

In constants.ts we have "infinite", "viewport", "inMemory" and "enterprise"

Setting row model to "normal" will cause one warning, whereas using "inMemory" will cause another.

I'd suggest a quick win would be to rename "normal" in RowModelClasses to "inMemory" would probably solve this but I don't know what other consequences there'd be

In a nutshell - should inMemory or normal be used for the default row model

fields.description:
john.MANDIA@uk.bnpparibas.com>

I’ve got a team who were having a bit of a problem ag-grid-enterprise and typescript and I helped them out.

 

The problem boiled down to the fact that we would like them to use import { LicenseManager } from ‘ag-grid-enterprise’;  instead of import { LicenseManager } from ‘ag-grid-enterprise/main’;.

 

The reason being we don’t want to webpack the file into our bundle and we want to fetch the minified single file (there are lots of different things we could do but we have a specific setup).

 

import { Grid } from ‘ag-grid’; works because you have  "typings":"./main.d.ts" in the package.json. If I add this to the ag-grid-enterprise package.json typescript is happy and it means people can use  ‘ag-grid-enterprise/main’ or ‘ag-grid-enterprise’.

 

I’ve checked the package.json of the latest enterprise release and it still doesn’t have the typings entry.

Is this possible for future releases?

This is something we could work around but it may be something that helps other teams who have complex setups and I can’t see the harm in adding it J

If you need a Jira raised or a github issue please let me know.
fields.summary: Support direct import of enterprise exports

fields.description:
Works fine for InMemoryRowModel

The other row models leave this out on purpose, as it's tricky, as the data may not be loaded.

For ViewPort and Infinite, we could do a 'best efforts', ie select if all data is available in memory, others do not do anything.

For Enterprise, this will be a headache, so don't think it's worth the effort in Enterprise (unless start row and end row are part of the same cache, then it might be easy enough).

Whatever we do here, it should be documented clearly, so users don't compalin.

Related to https://ag-grid.atlassian.net/browse/AG-134

fields.description:
Delta updates (as a result of rowNode.setDataValue()) will get called every time. Currently the provided the AnimateShowChangeCellRenderer has some logic in it's refresh method, where it checks and doesn't do the refresh if no change.

Niall note: I think this is best done where refresh would be called on the cellRenderer - and don't call refresh (or replace the cell if refresh is missing) if the values are different.

This should only work for strings and numbers. If the type is not string or number, then refresh - as the user will probably have their own cellRenderer anyway if it's an object, and they can do the checking in their (in the refresh method).
fields.summary: [delta] Have logic so delta update doesn't refresh if no change

Hi Niall,
 
Thanks for adding the getDocument() method in the gridOptions. This has partially solved the problem when I am re-ordering the columns. However resizing columns doesn’t seem to work.

I have replied to the original question in the forum thread as well.
 
The post is here: https://ag-grid.com/forum/showthread.php?tid=4558&pid=12586#pid12586
 
Looking forward to you reply.

fields.description:
Select all header checkbox is not working well when the grid pagination is in place. If you select the header checkbox, it selects all the records on the first page which is perfectly fine. But when you go to the next page, the header checkbox shows still selected (it should not show it selected). In short the state of the header checkbox is not maintained when pagination is in place.

fields.description:
I've created a plunker of this problem: https://plnkr.co/edit/QCJiRGuiNKwz5RwpJduU?p=preview

1. Edit a year cell with 2008
2. Change to 2009
3. The CSS class is retain despite a different value.

*Please note:* when .api.refreshView() is used to refresh the cells the CSS class is removed but doesn't return when you add 2008 as cell value.

From forum user:

So I'm having a column function for colDefs.cellClass that determines a specific class (returned string value) for the cell if grid data is in certain state. When the boolean condition passes it correctly adds my class to ag-cell div. But when I modify the cell data back to state where this condition doesn't pass, it still keeps my class in the ag-cell div. It should remove it since I'm not returning anything if this condition doesn't pass. I also tried returning null or "" when this condition doesn't pass but the my class persists.

fields.description:
logger.ts import decorators @Bean and @Qualifier from context/context.ts.
context/context.ts imports class Logger from logger.ts. Logger class is used by class Context in context/context.ts.
When CommonJS is used as module system, this circular dependency is ok. However, with ADM modules
this dependency can not be resolved, and @Bean decorator is undefined in Logger class.

*See Github page for more info:* https://github.com/ceolter/ag-grid/issues/1476
fields.summary: [context] Bad circular dependency: context/context.ts and logger.ts

fields.description:
*Comment from Github user:*

*Current behavior*
GridApi.refreshCells(rowNodes: RowNode[], colIds: string[], animate?: boolean): void takes a string[] as a parameter (colIds), although in the end the function to evaluate them is ColumnController.getGridColumn(key: string|ColDef|Column) (and 'obviously' it works with ColDefs and Columns just fine).

It appears that this chain is in general "wierdly" typed, with RowRenderer.refreshCells(rowNodes: RowNode[], colIds: string[], animate = false): voidand RenderedRows.refreshCells(colIds: string[], animate: boolean): void all taking a string[], whereas ColumnController.getGridColumns(keys: any[]): Column[] takes an any[] to call ColumnController.getGridColumn(key: string|ColDef|Column).

*Expected behavior*
Methods that accept string|ColDef|Column as a paremeter should also have that included in their type annotations to avoid constant casting to <any> (or facing compiler errors otherwise).
fields.summary: [typescript] Type annotations are incorrect for refreshCells

fields.description:
I am facing a problem when I need to create columns dynamically (using angular2 components as renderer) and more than one ag-grid-ng2 is in the page. When a create the columns, they are binded to the latest ag-grid-g2 component (viewContainerRef) that has been loaded.

This is a problem for me because I have a scenario that I create multiple grids, but only load the columns of the first grid in the end. So when I dynamically create the columns of the first grid, all the Renderer Components are binded to the latest grid. As all the grids are inside a Modal except by the first grid, when I close the modal, all the other grids are destroyed with the Renderer components and the events that I have inside this components.

As I know this could be difficult to understand, I have created an app to reproduce the problem. The steps are in the page:
ag-grid-ng2 viewContainerRef.zip

This problem is caused (in my opinion) because the Ng2FrameworkFactory is a singleton and it has the reference to the ag-grid-ng2 instance (viewContainerRef). So, every time a ag-grid-ng2 is created, it overrides the last viewContainerRef. Also, the setColumnDefs function uses the viewContainerRef provided by the Ng2FrameworkFactory.
fields.summary: [angular 2+] Multiple grids on page can cause issues with dynamic (angular) components

fields.description:
First of all: thanks a lot for the new export to Excel feature! It will make our customer really really happy.

Is there a reason why only cellClassRules are mapped to Excel styles? 

If I values to be aligned right (assuming a corresponding ExcelStyle in the GridOptions) I would define the column defs as follows:

Code:
cellClassRules: {
    alignRight: (params) => true
  }

Instead of the simpler, more straight forward:

Code:
cellClass: 'alignRight'


Alberto - for this, use colDef.cellClass to pull out the classes, then continue like the cellClassRules
